You're walking in the woods.
There's no one around, 
And your phone is dead.

Shia Labeouf.

About 30 feet back.
He gets down on all fours and breaks into a sprint.
He's gaining on you.
Shia Labeouf.

You're looking for your car, 
But you're all turned around.
He's almost upon you now
And you can see there's blood on his face! 
My god, there's blood everywhere! 

Running for your life

comments.text:

doing similar work. As a performance artist myself I know that at times

hold her as the barre but the work comes way before her and Shia is an

comments.text:
+knut761​​​​ "on which three counties are located..." three counties that 
are not sovereign, three countries that are part of the sovereign state of 
the United Kingdom ... also known colloquially as simply "Britain."

And it's at this point that we'd have to get into a long complicated 
conversation on the messy history of these countries and what's really at 
the crux of my argument here -- received pronunciation.

But yeah, I think we'll just have to chalk this one up to agreeing to 
disagree.

Funny story... This is just like a conversation that I got into with a 
Brazilian classmate one time. She refused to believe that Brazil was part 
of Latin America because "we were never conquered by the Spanish and we do 
not speak Spanish."

I just nodded my head because I didn't want to be rude, but Brazil is part 
of Latin America as far as most of us are concerned. It's a South American 
country and they still speak Portugese, a Latin language, and even some 
Brazilians I've met told me they believe they're part of Latin America as 
well.

But what it really comes down to is perspective. And since that's where we 
seem to be disagreeing, it's always best to just bow out.

But once again, it was great talking to you. And I'm being sincere when I 
say you've given me a lot to think about. (Sometimes people think I'm being 
sarcastic lol) You're obviously a very, very bright dude. And anyone who 
cares enough about languages and linguistics to be that specific is truly a 
man after my own heart lol

Have a good one!
comments.author: Steven René August DeCesare

comments.text:
+Steven René August DeCesare The United States is a country. Britain is an 
island... on which three countries are located. Note the difference. And 
yes, one has to be specific, unless the intent is to confuse people. 

What you could say would be, English spoken in the British Isles. Again, 
three different countries make up the Union. It is different. 

And to expand on list in my previous post...

America > American people > English language > American English > American 
English accents and dialects > insert regional accent / dialect spoken. 

(Yes I know America is a continent but I can't bring myself to call you 
"United Statiens" or "citizens of the United States") 

You are Americans :D Oh, and by the way, some humour here. You don't speak 
American English or English at all, you speak the *freedom language* ;)

Take one from the South, the Tidewater accent. Take one from the North, the 
Bostonian accent. 

So to recap....

England > English people > English language > English accents and dialects 
> insert regional accent / dialect spoken. 

Sweden > Swedish people > Swedish language > Swedish accents and dialects > 
insert regional accent / dialect spoken.

France > French people > French language > French accents and dialects > 
insert regional accent / dialect spoken.

etc etc etc.﻿

Discourse should always be civil, no point in being rude, great discussion 
I really liked it. Yeah, we disagree but that's cool.

Take care buddy.
comments.author: knut761

comments.text:
+knut761​​​​​ I can see where we're disagreeing perfectly now. You're 
looking at the Scottish and the Welsh dialects as their own categories 
entirely. (Or, in your words, more specifically.) But we still refer to 
those dialects as subcategories of "British English." Why? Because it's 
still Britain. It's still the British Isle and it's still the United 
Kingdom. Therefore, it's still British English as far as we're concerned. 
And it's a dialect because of what we refer to as "received pronunciation" 
which is the closest thing to a "standard accent" that the U.K. has ever 
seen.

So I guess what I'm trying to say is that I disagree with your assertion 
that one "has to be specific." No, one doesn't. If what I'm talking about 
is the English spoken in the United Kingdom, inclusive of all sub-dialects 
and regionalisms, emphasizing received pronunciation, which I am, then I'm 
going to refer to it as "British English."

But if you want to stick to your guns, and you truly believe in being 
consistent, then let's do the same with the English spoken in the U.S. From 
now on, there's no such thing as "American English." There will be New 
England English, New York English, Old Country Southern English... etc. We 
can come up with dozens and dozens of more specific categories.

Or... you know... we can just refer to it as American English and British 
English when we're not being specific. And that's what we do.

At any rate, I guess we'll just have to agree to disagree. Thanks for 
keeping the conversation civil though. This was really good. You gave me a 
lot to think about. Cheers! (Yeah we say that here too lol)﻿

EDIT: This page has a little tree diagram that makes it clear. It all falls 
under "British English." And then just look up "received pronunciation" and 
it should make sense to you as to why we refer to it as a dialect.

http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Languages_of_the_United_Kingdom
comments.author: Steven René August DeCesare

comments.text:
+Steven René August DeCesare No offence but you're confused, and this 
confusion is typical for Americans. Not your fault. 

There are no British English dialect, same thing that there is no such 
thing as a European dialect. Yet people say that too. Doesn't make it 
correct though. 

There are English, Scottish, and Welsh dialects spoken in Britain. (English 
people, Scottish people, and Welsh people) But there are *no* British

Again, you have to be specific as I mentioned in my previous post. Are you

comments.author: knut761

comments.text:
+knut761 English is a language, and British English is a dialect. Yes it is 
a dialect. I'm not really sure where to go from here because -- and again, 
I'm really honestly not trying to be condescending or rude -- but any 
linguist will tell you that yes, it's a dialect and yes, it's "British 
English."

There are 3 main dialects of English: the English of Great Britain/the 
U.K., the English of North America, and the English of Australasia. They're 
considered dialects because they differ not only in pronunciation, but 
grammar and spelling.

So I'm not really sure what else to say. If you don't want to believe me, 
then that's OK. But the entirety of the field of linguistics would 
absolutely and unequivocally agree with me upon those two points. And of 
that I'm absolutely certain.

You have to remember that it's not just pronunciation. So while one's 
accent might differ in one part of Great Britain or what have you, or even 
in different parts of England itself, it's still considered a dialect of 
English that we refer to as "British English."

Like I said, you don't have to agree, and you can continue referring to it 
as "English English" if you'd like, but just know that it's not what it is 
and not because I say so but because it's what essentially the whole body 
of linguistic scholarship says... so, there you go. You know?
comments.author: Steven René August DeCesare

comments.text:
+Steven René August DeCesare "British English" makes no sense, it is 
neither a language or an accent or dialect. 

You have English accents and dialects, you have Scottish accents and 
dialects, and Welsh accents and dialects. You have to be specific. 

Look, I get what you mean but it gets confusing when you say "British". 
Same thing when someone says European accent, well there are no European 
accent, or dialect, or language. 

Yes English accents can sound both uneducated and educated, some even 
funny, same thing with Southern American accents and dialects. I prefer 
Southern American accents because they sound warm and polite, I also like 
the sentence structure they use. 

I was a bit harsh about Yank accents, the Bostonian accent is kind of nice, 
and there are a couple of other ones (can't recall now) but generally 
speaking it sounds so...flat. 

Too you it's different I guess, over here in Europe there are sooo many 
different accents and dialects. In my own country, the size of California, 
we have around 100 different, population around 8 million.
comments.author: knut761

comments.text:
+knut761​ No it's not an erroneous term. It's British English, the form of 
English written and spoken throughout all of Britain, the British Isles, 
not just in England. And that's why we refer to it as British English. If 
we were referring to the English written and spoken only in England, then 
yes, it would be "English English" I guess, but we're not; we're talking 
about the English spoken throughout the entirety of Britain. I'm not being 
condescending here, and I'm not trying to insult you, but do you understand 
how England relates to Great Britain and how Great Britain relates to the 
United Kingdom? It's British English we're talking about here, not English 
English. I've never heard anyone, any learned person (we actually say that 
here too), ever speak of "English English."

But as for us sounding like robots, no offense taken. I don't really know 
what we sound like because it's always been what I've heard most often. 
British English can sound either incredibly silly or incredibly smart and 
sophisticated depending upon the regional dialect. The southern American 
dialect sounds so unsophisticated and ridiculous to my ears. But that's me.
comments.author: Steven René August DeCesare

comments.text:
+Steven René August DeCesare It's "English English" the English spawned the 
language, the clue is in the name. "British English" is actually an 
erroneous term. Yes I know most use it but it's not really accurate. But I 
digress.

As for the difference between American English and English English it 
resembles that of French and Canadian French. Which is more proper can be 
debated, however, I would argue that American English is poorer than 
English English when it comes to expression. Then again, English as a 
language is much poorer than other European languages, it lacks nuances 
etc. 

Perhaps that makes sense since it is a much younger language than say 
Swedish, German and French. 

If you look at the word "learned" that is also a term that the English use 
(which doesn't exist in American English) example: learned man.  

Lastly, when it comes to spelling as I touched upon that is the handy work 
of Noah Webster, most of it, he wanted to simply the language, and at the 
same time distance the Americans from the English. If not you would have 
spelled like the English, Canadians, Australians and Kiwis do. 

I'm not putting any value on it, to be honest, the most beautiful English 
spoken is a well spoken Southern dialect/accent. Nothing comes close to 
that, imo. 

Yanks all sound like monotone robots, un-alive, there is no anima there, no 
nuances.. That is not to offend them but it's true. If I were to picture 
the way they speak t it would be a flat line.
comments.author: knut761
